title: 113_s1126
content: The "Prescribe A Book Act" establishes Pediatric Early Literacy Programs under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. It includes definitions for pediatric involvement in reading and education. The "Prescribe A Book Act" defines an eligible entity as a nonprofit organization with proven effectiveness in providing peer-to-peer training on literacy promotion to healthcare providers. This training is delivered through various medical education settings. The "Prescribe A Book Act" aims to promote pediatric literacy through training programs in medical education settings and providing technical assistance to healthcare facilities for implementing a Pediatric Early Literacy Program. Additionally, it offers discounted books to local healthcare facilities. The "Prescribe A Book Act" includes providing technical assistance and discounted books to local healthcare facilities for implementing a Pediatric Early Literacy Program, integrating research into training for healthcare providers. The "Prescribe A Book Act" integrates developmental and educational research into healthcare provider training for a Pediatric Early Literacy Program. The "Pediatric Early Literacy Program" involves healthcare providers promoting early language and literacy by encouraging parents to read aloud to their children. The "Pediatric Early Literacy Program" encourages parents to read aloud to young children and provides developmentally appropriate recommendations. Healthcare providers give children aged 6 months to 5 years a new book at health visits. Volunteers in waiting areas also support literacy efforts. The "Pediatric Early Literacy Program" provides children aged 6 months to 5 years with new books at health visits and encourages reading aloud. Volunteers in waiting areas also promote literacy by reading aloud to children. The "Pediatric Early Literacy Program" promotes reading aloud to children in healthcare facilities, demonstrating effectiveness in improving parent behavior and language skills in young children, and receiving endorsements from medical associations. The Secretary is authorized to award grants to eligible entities for Pediatric Early Literacy Programs. Eligible entities must submit an application to the Secretary and meet matching requirements. An eligible entity seeking a grant for Pediatric Early Literacy Programs must submit an application to the Secretary with required information. The entity receiving the grant must provide non-Federal matching funds equal to at least 50% of the grant received. The grant funds must be used as specified. An eligible entity receiving a grant for Pediatric Early Literacy Programs must enter into contracts with private nonprofit organizations or public agencies to establish and operate the program. The entity must also provide training and technical assistance to contractors and include terms and conditions determined by the Secretary in the agreement. The Early Literacy Program requires eligible entities to contract with private nonprofit organizations or public agencies to establish and operate the program. Contractors must prioritize serving at-risk children, including those from low-income families. Training, technical assistance, and additional terms and conditions are provided to ensure program effectiveness. Contractors for the Early Literacy Program must prioritize serving at-risk children, including those from low-income families, without adequate medical insurance, and enrolled in Medicaid. Children who should be prioritized for the Early Literacy Program include those from low-income families, without adequate medical insurance, enrolled in Medicaid, living in rural areas, migrant children, and those with limited access to libraries. The Secretary must ensure that eligible entities have arrangements with book publishers or distributors to obtain books at favorable discounts before making any payments under this subpart. Additionally, there is a reporting requirement outlined in Section 5627. The reporting requirement in Section 5627 mandates eligible entities to report annually on program effectiveness, including contractor programs. A conforming amendment adds a new subpart for pediatric early literacy programs. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act is amended to include a new subpart for pediatric early literacy programs, outlining definitions, program authorization, applications, matching requirements, use of grant funds, restrictions on payments, and reporting requirements.
